item.title: Full MiDOC Procedure Test on Porcine Eye
item.description:
The goal of this test is to understand how the eye responds to fluid and pressure before and after a surgical procedure. By raising the IV bag, we create gentle pressure changes in the eye and record how it responds. Then, we perform a procedure to create a tiny leak in the eye and repeat the pressure changes. This creates signature features in the pressure and flow data that reveals post-operative insights.


Setup the MiDOC and insert it into the eye
Create 3 Pressure Impulses by elevating the height of the IV bag to create a signature which captures features such as the ocular compliance / outflow facility of the eye
Continue with the surgical procedure (in this case a 30g needle was inserted into the eye to induce a leak)
Repeat step 2 to capture Pressure and Flow features after the surgical intervention



The goal of this test is to demonstrate the functionality of the device by creating varying sizes of leaks in the eye and observing the Pressure and Flow responses.

IV bag -> MiDOC -> 22g needle -> AC
AC -> stop cock -> 25g vs 27g vs 30g needle -> air


Allow the IOP to stabilize to the IV bag pressure
Screw in the 25g needle
Open the stop cock to induce a leak through the needle to air
Repeat for the 27g and 30g needle









Place the sensors on a level surface
Connect the sensors to the MiDOC
- P3 is upstream
- P4 is downstream
Launch the MiDOC program
Tare in air
hook up the setup (below)
IV Bag -> Infusion Set -> Stop Cock 1 -> Microbore Tubing -> P3 -> Microbore Tubing -> 27g x half inch Needle -> Injection Site -> P4 -> 22g x 1/2" Needle
Squeeze the Infusion Set and open the air relief valve until the vial is at least 3/4 full
Purge the lines ensuring there is absolutely no air anywhere inline
Secure the sensors to a level surface
Lower the height of the IV bag to 30 mmHg (the lowest mark)
Press start on the MiDOC
Make the incision and insert the needle into the anterior chamber
Add a "MiDOC insertion" comment
Wait 15 s
Stop the flow using the stop cock
Raise the height of the IV bag by 10 mmHg
Quickly enable the flow using the stop cock
Add a "Raise Bag Step X" comment
Repeat steps (10-13) 3X additional times
Wait 15 seconds
Lower the IV bag to the initial height (30 mmHg - the lowest mark)
Continue monitoring and add procedure comments appropriately
After surgical intervention steps repeat steps (10-14)
Stop the MiDOC

item.title: Overview
item.description:
The MiDOC is an ophthalmic surgical device/setup to collect intra-operative data on the outflow facility and Intraoperative Pressure (IOP) in patients in an attempt to correlate a "successful" surgery to one or more measurable intraoperative parameters. The MiDOC is comprised of 2 pressure sensors and a flow restrictor between them that is connected in-line with an IV bag to measure the change in flow and pressure during surgery. We perform and compare tests both pre- and post-intervention which consist of a series of pressure increase steps to determine the success of the surgery. It has been tested on enucleated porcine eyes to demonstrate its accuracy and is nearing a point where it is ready to begin data collection in real world scenarios. The following documents are ready to review to determine any remaining issues with the functionality of the device.

MiDOC Overview Video
Pressure Step Demonstration Video








Place the sensors on a level surface
Connect the sensors to the MiDOC
- P3 is upstream
- P4 is downstream
Launch the MiDOC program
Tare in air
hook up the setup (below)
IV Bag -> Infusion Set -> Stop Cock 1 -> Microbore Tubing -> P3 -> Microbore Tubing -> 27g x half inch Needle -> Injection Site -> P4 -> 22g x 1/2" Needle
Squeeze the Infusion Set and open the air relief valve until the vial is at least 3/4 full
Purge the lines ensuring there is absolutely no air anywhere inline
Secure the sensors to a level surface
Lower the height of the IV bag to 30 mmHg (the lowest mark)
Press start on the MiDOC
Make the incision and insert the needle into the anterior chamber
Add a "MiDOC insertion" comment
Wait 15 s
Stop the flow using the stop cock
Raise the height of the IV bag by 10 mmHg
Quickly enable the flow using the stop cock
Add a "Raise Bag Step X" comment
Repeat steps (10-13) 3X additional times
Wait 15 seconds
Lower the IV bag to the initial height (30 mmHg - the lowest mark)
Continue monitoring and add procedure comments appropriately
After surgical intervention steps repeat steps (10-14)
Stop the MiDOC


This is an example of a mock surgery on a porcine eye to show flow and pressure capabilities.
250321 - Full Procedure Testing

This is how we calibrated the pressure drop across the restriction to align with the readings from a sensiron flow sensor.
250228 - 250305 MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Testing
250307 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship
250310 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship
250311 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship

These are some tests that verify the accuracy of our pressure sensors
250318 - MiDOC Pressure Sensor Consistency Testing

An explanation of each source of error, it’s effect on each variable, and the changes we made to the procedure to mitigate it.
MiDOC - Potential Sources of Error Analysis > All Potential Sources of Error

item.title: Setup
item.description:
Place the sensors on a level surface
Connect the sensors to the MiDOC
- P3 is upstream
- P4 is downstream
Launch the MiDOC program
Tare in air (refer to 250310 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship > Proposed Solution)
hook up the setup (below)
IV Bag -> Infusion Set -> Stop Cock 1 -> Microbore Tubing -> P3 -> Microbore Tubing -> 27g x half inch Needle -> Injection Site -> P4 -> 22g x 1.5"
Anterior Chamber -> Stop Cock 2 -> 27g x 1/2" needle -> Ambiant
Purge the lines ensuring there is absolutely no air anywhere inline
Secure the sensors to a level surface
Lower the height of the IV bag to 30 mmHg (the lowest mark)
Press start on the MiDOC
Make the incision and insert the AC Maintainer
Wait 5 s
Add a test start comment
Wait 15 s
Stop the flow using Stop Cock 1
Add a raise pressure comment
Raise the height of the IV bag by 13 mmHg (The next mark up - 8.028 inches)
Quickly enable the flow using the stop cock
Wait 15 s
Repeat steps (10-13) 2X additional times
Add a test end comment
Lower the IV bag to the initial height (30 mmHg - the lowest mark)
Continue monitoring and add procedure comments appropriately
Quickly enable flow through Stop Cock 2 and (i.e. ) repeat steps (9-15) once.
Stop the MiDOC


Need to ensure every connection makes sense (e.g. luer locks fit together)
Purging the line after the silicone injection port requires a time delay that is a function of volume after the injection port. Using a thinner iv tubing would be helpful.

Labels = {
7.2: "MiDOC Insertion",
43: "Stop Cock Off",
53.8: "Pressure Impulse 1",
75.5: "Stop Cock Off",
86.2: "Pressure Impulse 2",
107.2: "Stop Cock Off",
122.5: "Pressure Impulse 3",
169: "Surgical Procedure",
231.5: "Ouflow Needle Insertion",
260: "Stop Cock Off",
270.8: "Pressure Impulse 1",
286.9: "Stop Cock Off",
295.9: "Pressure Impulse 2",
314.2: "Stop Cock Off",
324: "Pressure Impulse 3",
}
item.guid: mount_sinai-notes/projects/MiDOC/Testing/full procedure porcine testing/250317 - Full Procedure Testing.md

item.title: 250321 - Full Procedure Testing
item.description:
Goal
Run through the full MiDOC procedure on a porcine eye.
A 27 gauge needle is inserted and removed into the AC to create a small leak that is not percievable with the human eye.
Verify if we can observe the increase in outflow facility after this leak is created.


Place the sensors on a level surface
Connect the sensors to the MiDOC
- P3 is upstream
- P4 is downstream
Launch the MiDOC program
Tare in air
hook up the setup (below)
IV bag -> Infusion Set -> Stop Cock 1 -> microbore tubing -> P3 -> microbore tubing -> 27g x half inch Needle -> Injection Site -> P4 -> 22g x 1.5"
Purge the lines ensuring there is absolutely no air anywhere inline
Secure the sensors to a level surface
Lower the height of the IV bag to 30 mmHg (the lowest mark)
Press start on the MiDOC and add a MiDOC Insertion Comment
Insert the MiDOC
Wait 15 s
Stop the flow using the Stop Cock
Raise the height of the IV bag by 1"
Quickly enable the flow using the stop cock
Add a raise pressure comment
Wait 90 s
Repeat steps (10-13) 9X additional times
Lower the IV bag to the initial height (30 mmHg - the lowest mark)
Continue monitoring and add procedure comments appropriately
Insert a 27g needle into the AC and immediately remove it (to create a leak) repeat steps (9-14).
Stop the MiDOC

After each bag raise (pressure increase step), the exponential decay curve of the pressure, and exponential growth curve of the flow are extracted.
An exponential curve is fitted to the pressure and flow vs time graphs for each pressure increase step. These exponential curves for the 10 pressure steps before and 10 pressure steps after the creation of the leak is shown in the top two plots in the below figure.
The asymptote of this curve is then extracted and used to plot flow vs pressure. There will therefore be 1 flow vs pressure data point for each pressure infusion step. This is shown in the bottom 2 plots in the below figure.

The steady state pressure values are clearly lower after the procedure, and the flow values are clearly higher (Top two plots).
The flow vs pressure graph shows a slope of 0 ul/min/mmHg before the procedure which indicates a good seal and no leak (bottom left plot).
The flow vs pressure graph shows a slope of 0.3 ul/min/mmHg after the procedure which indicates a ~18ul/min leak at an IOP of around 20 mmHg (bottom right plot).

Some are very good, some not so much. Might help to filter out the oscillations.
Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 1: 0.9237 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 1: 0.9326 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 2: 0.6397 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 2: 0.9530 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 3: 0.8711 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 3: 0.9290 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 4: 0.8892 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 4: 0.9102 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 5: 0.9204 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 5: 0.9620 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 6: 0.9274 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 6: 0.9316 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 7: 0.5600 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 7: 0.9231 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 8: 0.9056 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 8: 0.9375 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 9: 0.1155 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 9: 0.9117 Pressure fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 10: 0.7828 Flow fit R² for Pre Raise Bag Step 10: 0.9436 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 1: 0.9873 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 1: 0.9744 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 2: 0.7558 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 2: 0.8282 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 3: 0.8285 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 3: 0.9308 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 4: 0.7173 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 4: 0.8376 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 5: 0.7104 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 5: 0.8868 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 6: 0.9072 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 6: 0.9476 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 7: 0.6893 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 7: 0.8453 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 8: 0.7789 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 8: 0.8756 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 9: 0.7532 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 9: 0.8506 Pressure fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 10: 0.4544 Flow fit R² for Post Raise Bag Step 10: 0.7791

The pressure and flow values for each pressure raise step was allowed to reach steady state in this test by waiting for roughly 90 seconds. However, we will not have this much time during an actual human test case.
For this reason it was desired to know how the accuracy of the calculated outflow facility changes (as compared to the calculated value using all the data) when only a subset of the pvt and fvt data is used.
To determine this, the pvt and fvt plots were trimmed at various times, then the exponential fitting and outlfow calculation was computed using this trimmed data. The resulting outflow facility value was then compared to the value obtained when using the full 90 seconds.
The following figure shows the resulting accuracy as a function of the time alloted for each pressure raise step.

The accuracy seems unstable from 0 to 20 seconds and starts to converge afterwards.
This test provoked the change from the initially proposed waiting time of 15 seconds in the procedure with 4 pressure increase steps, to a waiting time of 30 seconds with only 3 pressure infusion steps. Increasing the total test time from 1 minute to 1.5 minutes.
The following plots convey the same information as shown at the top of this results discussion but when the data is trimmed at various times. The calculated value for Slope (outflow facility) clearly starts inaccurate and slowly approaches the full time value.





The following figures show the raw pvt and fvt plots on top.
On bottom is the fitted exponentials overlayed on top of the filtered pvt and fvt data.
image-84.png
image-85.png
image-86.png
image-87.png
image-88.png
image-89.png
image-90.png
image-91.png
image-92.png
image-93.png
image-94.png
image-95.png
image-96.png
image-97.png
image-98.png
image-99.png
image-100.png

item.title: Goal
item.description:
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/4gce2eovt7grbk3m6cl60/APTSBY7XXUmeLG7K-A80lY0?rlkey=k703vfad895gahunf0p4bnkwn&dl=0

Determine how consistently different pressure sensors of the same type scale in output when exposed to varying magnitudes of pressusre


Elevated IV Bag -> P3 -> P4 -> Stop Cock
Fill up the IV bag to 45 mmHg
Open the stop cock and let the water drain until the pressure drops by 8 mmHg
Stop the stop cock
Take 5 s of data with the MiDOC
Append the data to a file titled with the index of the downstream sensor
repeat steps (2-6) 4 times
Once the fluid runs out switch out the downstream pressure sensor with a new one and create a new pressure sensor file
Load the files and analyze.py to analyze the standard deviation of the pressure differential between the sensors


NOTE: The sensors are not tared so the important attribute of this plot is that the lines are consistent and horizontal, not that they should all lie on the same y value.

Overall Average Standard Deviation: 0.03 mm Hg
item.guid: mount_sinai-notes/projects/MiDOC/Testing/pressure sensor consistency testing/250318 - MiDOC Pressure Sensor Consistency Testing.md

item.title: Objective
item.description:
To identify sources of error for the MiDOC device, their magnitudes, and the methods to mitigate them.


Movement of the eye / patient / surgeon
Oscillations of the IV Bag
Blockages & Kinks in the Line
Leveling
Vibrations in the room / Enviroment
People walking
Surrounding equipment (Heating / AC, Cooling fans in nearby electronics)
Air In Line
Leaks
Raising Bag Live
Sensor Calibration
Temperature
In Line Flow Vectoring
Rotation/Orientation of the needle (how straight it is inserted and which way the opening is facing)
Location of the needle (how centered it is when inserted)
IOP Calculation from P4


Effect: Extremely High
Mitigation: Everyone needs to stay still during data collection.

Effect: The IV bag swinging on the pole causes a certain amount of pressure fluctuations during the procedure as outlined below. If we have an IV bag with the following characteristics

IV bag height: 10 inches
Swing angle: 10 degrees
Density of the fluid: Assuming it’s water or a similar solution (ρ ≈ 1002 kg/m³)
Gravity: 9.81 m/s²
Pressure sensor is assumed to be at a fixed point below the IV bag.
When the IV bag swings, the vertical position of the lowest point of the bag changes. The height change (Δh) is given by:

where:

inches (converted to meters: )
(converted to radians: )
Now, calculating:
 
The pressure change due to a height difference (Δh) in a fluid column is:

Substituting values:
ΔP=(1000 kg/m3)×(9.81 m/s2)×(0.00386 m) ≈ 37.8 Pa ​≈ 0.28 mmHg
When raising and lowering the IV bag normally, it is unlikely to swing to a full 10 degrees. the amplitude and decay time of oscillations when raising and lowering the IV bag is tested in 250318 - MiDOC Bag Oscillation Testing which finds a maximum decay time of 12 seconds.
Mitigation: Wait 15 seconds after raising or lowering the IV bag prior to starting data collection. (Also pass visual inspection that the IV bag is not swinging)

Effect: High. This would be a dominate effect on the testing.
Mitigation: Ensure no blockages / kinks in the line prior to testing.
Example in 250307 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship > Compare Batch 4 and Batch 5
The kink in the microbore tubing increased the flow calculations by ~5 for the same pressure drop.

Effect: The effect of leveling the devices modifies the pressure sensor data by the following:

where:

is the height misalignment ()
is gravity (9.81)
is fluid density () (1002 kg/m^3)
The pressure sensors are a maximum distance of 6 inches apart so with a potential incline on the table of 5 degrees, we could have a vertical offset of up to:



so, therefore, the total inaccuracy between pressure sensors could be:

Mitigation: This 0.982 mm Hg would be a dominating factor of the calculation and therefore we must keep the devices level to within 0.1mmHg:

Maximum height discrepancy
Therefore, to achieve a pressure sensor accuracy of 0.1mmHg, the devices must be on a table with a maximum slant of:

We need to ensure the operating table is level prior to completing the test.
This was discovered/demonstrated in 250310 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship > Batch 4 in which the slope of the lines between batches was roughly equivalent but there existed an offset between them of ~5 for the same pressure drop.

TBD

Effect: Air bubbles trapped in the system introduce compliance, reducing the measured pressure difference.
Mitigation: Lines must be purged entirely prior to use of the MiDOC. Failure to do so will result in wildly varying results. Further, when priming the Infusion Set, we must open the air relief valve and squeeze the vial until largely full to ensure no air bubbles get sucked down the iv tube from the falling droplets.
This is demonstrated in 250310 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship > Batch 3 where the flow calculations are off by 10 to 15 between batches when there is air in line.

Effect: Any leak between the pressure sensors or after the pressure sensors in line will overshadow any calculation
Mitigation: Ensure the calculated flow is near zero when the stop cock is closed prior to the test. Use a proper silicon injection site instead of putting a needle through the side of an IV tube.
Was likely the major source of error in 250307 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship > Batch 1 and 2 with a maximum measured difference in flow of around 5 for the same pressure drop

Effect: Raising the IV Bag while being connected to the pressure sensors creates a large amount of oscillations and data noise from that inhibits proper measurement.
Mitigation: Using a Stop Cock in between the IV Bag and Pressure Sensor makes it possible to stop the flow before raising the bag. This prevents the vibrations caused by the shaking of the IV bag from transmitting to the pressure sensors.

Effect: The scaling and accuracy of the pressure sensors is documented in the testing: 250318 - MiDOC Pressure Sensor Consistency Testing




NOTE: The sensors are not tared so the important attribute of this plot is that the lines are consistent and horizontal, not that they should all lie on the same y value.

Overall Average Standard Deviation: 0.03 mm Hg
Mitigation: No mitigation is needed on this front as the average standard deviation of these sensors is 0.03 mm Hg.

Effect: The effect of the temperature on the flow calculation is shown below:

where:

​ is the sensor’s temperature coefficient (Pa/°C).
is the operating temperature.
​ is the calibration temperature.
If we calibrate the sensor at and measure the surgical case at , with the temperature coefficient of 0.2% per 10 K, the sensor may have a 0.2% offset.
From 70mmHg, this offset would be a 0.14 mm Hg difference. Fortunately, this should cancel out in the flow calculation math and only the pressure drop across the needle would have a 0.2% offset which, with a pressure drop of 5.0mmHg, would then yield a pressure offset of 0.01mmHg.
Mitigation: No mitigation is required for the temperature of these sensors as we are largely looking at the offset and therefore the effect of the temperature is minimal.

Could be a contributing source of error in 250307 - MiDOC Flow vs Pressure Relationship > Batch 1 and 2 with a maximum measured difference in flow of around 5 for the same pressure drop
However, this was likely due to a leak between the sensors from not using a proper injection site instead



Estimate the pressure drop for 0.5% saline (assume water-like viscosity) flowing through a 22-gauge cannula at 20 µL/min, with inner diameter 0.51 mm and length 1.5 inches (0.0381 m).
